explanation:
For each symbol: why it is needed to decide whether MHD_add_response_header modifies its parameters (violating the MISRA rule).

MHD_str_equal_caseless_: may be a macro or function. If a macro it could expand to code that assigns to the local identifiers header/content in the caller. We must inspect its definition to ensure it does not reassign the parameter variables.

add_response_header_connection: called within the function; if implemented as a macro it could reassign the identifier tokens (e.g. content) in the caller via macro expansion. If a function, it cannot reassign the caller's parameter variables. Need the definition/type.

add_response_entry: same rationale as add_response_header_connection — could be a macro wrapper that rewrites caller identifiers. Also it is used to add headers; inspect whether it is a macro or function and whether it assigns to any of the parameter names.

add_response_entry_n: add_response_entry may delegate to this; include to inspect implementations or macro wrappers that could modify caller parameter identifiers.

MHD_get_response_element_n_: called and its return used; include because it may be a macro and could expand in a way that assigns to caller identifiers. Also needed to understand the type of the returned pointer (struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *).

_MHD_remove_header: called to remove an element; could be a macro. Inspect to ensure it does not reassign any of the function parameters (e.g. response).

mhd_assert: usually a macro; inspect its definition because some assert macros may reference or assign to variables during expansion (rare but must be checked to be sure the parameter identifiers are not modified).

free: standard library function (or macro on some platforms). Included to confirm freeing operations do not reassign parameter variables; also to understand that freeing hdr->value, hdr->header modifies pointed-to objects (allowed) not the parameter pointer itself.

struct MHD_Response: definition required to confirm which modifications in the body are to the object pointed to (response->flags_auto |= ...) rather than to the parameter variable 'response' itself — modifications to the pointed object are permitted by the MISRA rule, but reassignment of the parameter variable would violate it.

struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header: its layout (members value, header) is needed to confirm the code touches members of a returned object and frees internal pointers (these are modifications of pointed-to objects, permitted) and to ensure no code assigns to the local parameter variables.

MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONNECTION, MHD_HTTP_HEADER_TRANSFER_ENCODING, MHD_HTTP_HEADER_DATE, MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_LENGTH: these may be macros (string constants) — include to inspect whether any of these are defined in a way that could expand to assignments to identifiers named header/content when used in macros like MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_.

MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_: macro used in an argument; inspect to ensure it does not expand to code that mutates caller parameters (e.g. via token 'header' or 'content').

MHD_HEADER_KIND: used as an argument; inspect its definition if macro to ensure it cannot reassign caller identifiers.

MHD_RAF_HAS_TRANS_ENC_CHUNKED, MHD_RAF_HAS_CONTENT_LENGTH, MHD_RAF_HAS_DATE_HDR, MHD_RF_INSANITY_HEADER_CONTENT_LENGTH, MHD_RF_HEAD_ONLY_RESPONSE: flag macros/defines used in bitwise operations and assignments to response->flags_auto/flags; include to confirm these are simple constants (no side effects) and to validate that changes are to the pointed-to object, not the parameter variable.

MHD_NO, MHD_YES: result constants (enum or macros). Include to ensure they are not macros with side effects that could reassign parameters.

Summary: any symbol used in this function that might be a macro must be inspected because C macros expand in the caller context and could, in principle, reassign the identifiers 'response', 'header', or 'content' — which would be a direct violation of the MISRA rule. Also include the struct/type and flag definitions so the analyzer can distinguish allowed modifications of the object pointed to from forbidden reassignment of the parameter variables.
